name: London
fun_fact: Fun fact: London is home to 270+ nationalities making it the world's most metropolitan city, with approximately 24,000 restaurants ranging from Michelin-starred fine dining to vibrant street food markets representing every corner of the globe.

hero_dishes.name: Brick Lane Curry
hero_dishes.description: Authentic Indian and Bangladeshi curries from London's iconic curry district, featuring rich, aromatic dishes that have been served since the 1970s
hero_dishes.origin_story: Brick Lane became London's curry capital as Bangladeshi immigrants settled in the East End, creating a vibrant food district that revolutionized British dining culture
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Brick Lane (East London), especially the historic curry houses that line this famous street

hero_dishes.name: Bombay-Inspired Comfort Food
hero_dishes.description: Modern Indian fusion dishes like the famous House Black Daal slow-cooked for 24 hours, allowing spices to fully develop
hero_dishes.origin_story: Dishoom revolutionized London's Indian food scene by recreating the nostalgic Bombay cafÃ© culture with quirky dÃ©cor and innovative fusion dishes
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Dishoom (multiple locations: King's Cross, Shoreditch, Covent Garden, with new opening at London Bridge near Borough Market)

hero_dishes.name: Sri Lankan Hoppers
hero_dishes.description: Bowl-shaped fermented rice pancakes with crispy edges and soft centers, served with bold curries and sambols
hero_dishes.origin_story: JKS Restaurant Group brought authentic Sri Lankan street food to Soho, later expanding to showcase South Indian dishes alongside traditional hoppers

hero_dishes.name: West African Jollof & Caribbean Jerk
hero_dishes.description: Spicy West African rice dishes and Jamaican jerk chicken with authentic island flavors
hero_dishes.origin_story: Brixton Village Market became London's Caribbean and African food hub, preserving immigrant food traditions while creating new fusion innovations
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Brixton Village and Market Row (South London)

hero_dishes.name: Vietnamese Pho
hero_dishes.description: Aromatic beef or chicken noodle soup with fresh herbs, served in authentic Vietnamese style
hero_dishes.origin_story: Kingsland Road in East London earned the nickname 'Pho Mile' for its incredible concentration of authentic Vietnamese restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Middle Eastern Mezze
hero_dishes.description: Authentic Lebanese, Syrian, and Egyptian small plates featuring hummus, falafel, grilled meats, and fresh flatbreads
hero_dishes.origin_story: Edgware Road became London's Little Arabia, with bustling markets and late-night eateries serving the city's Middle Eastern community

hero_dishes.name: Korean BBQ & Kimchi
hero_dishes.description: Tabletop grilled meats, bibimbap, and fermented vegetables from London's Korean enclave
hero_dishes.origin_story: New Malden became Europe's largest Korean community outside of Korea, creating an authentic slice of Seoul in suburban London

signature_drinks.name: Craft Cocktails
signature_drinks.description: Innovative fusion cocktails reflecting London's multicultural identity, from yuzu whisky sours to masala chai martinis
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Londoners explore cocktail bars across neighborhoods like Shoreditch and Soho, embracing experimental flavors that blend global influences

signature_drinks.name: Artisan Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Third-wave coffee culture with beans sourced from around the world, reflecting London's global connections
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Flat whites and pour-overs consumed in independent cafÃ©s while working or meeting friends

signature_drinks.name: Craft Beer & Ale
signature_drinks.description: Both traditional British ales and modern craft beers from London's booming brewery scene
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed in historic pubs or trendy taprooms, often paired with food from nearby market stalls

food_culture_notes: London has 85 Michelin-starred restaurants as of 2025, including six three-star establishments
Borough Market remains the heart of London's food scene with artisanal cheeses, fresh breads, and international delicacies from Ethiopian stews to Argentinian empanadas
Street food festivals have become melting pots where vendors experiment with fusion like Thai-British combinations and West African jollof paired with Korean pickles
The city's food markets are social hubs where global cuisines meet local produce - from historic Borough Market to trendy Maltby Street Market
2025 food trends include experimental hybrids and pan-Asian fusion dishes that celebrate London's diversity
It's completely normal to find Sunday roast reimagined with miso gravy and tempura vegetables, showcasing London's creative food culture
